media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 11th August 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:54 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
05:07 - Welcome and Lighting of peace candle (by Duty Elder)
06:35 - Call to worship
Good Shepherd, remind us that we are your little flock, gathered by your spirit, and tended through your love. May we know your presence as we worship today. Amen
07:43 - 10:47 - Hymn R&S 552 The King of love
11:03 - 12:30 - Reading Psalm 23 A simple meditation on Psalm 23 ‚Äì read by Kate Yates
12:44 - 14:40 - Prayer of Confession and Assurance of Forgiveness We come before God held in the knowledge we are loved, and with assurance that we are transformed through God‚Äôs love. Loving shepherd, we come to you to confess That there are times when we live like sheep without a shepherd. Times we allow our busyness to drive us from places of rest. Times we choose paths of discord rather than loving kindness. Times we embrace despair rather than hope Jesus is the good shepherd who has pity on his flock And promises goodness and love will be with us Follow your shepherd on the right paths, And do so in the knowledge you are loved and forgiven. Amen.
The Lord‚Äôs Prayer
14:49 - HYMN R&S 289 To God be the Glory
19:01 - 21:05 - Reading: Mark 6: 30-34, 53-56 read by Harri Bello
21:32 - Hymn R&S 197 Jesus Hands were Kind Hands
23:03 - 32:47 - Address:
32:59 - 36:11 - HYMN R&S 349 I heard the voice of Jesus say
36:20 - 39:47 - Prayers of Intercession for the World
Offering Prayer (for our gifts this last week and today)
God has gifted us everything needed for every human being on earth to have a good and fruitful life. We need only be ready to share what we ourselves have been blessed to receive. Let us pray: God, in response to your great love and generosity, we offer our gifts of money and the gift of our lives. Use them for good, as we seek to serve you and our fellow humans in love. Amen.
43:04 - HYMN R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
46:10 - 46:31 - Closing blessing
46:59 - 50:05 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 7th July 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:09 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
04:23 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:21 - Call to worship (from Isaiah 6. 1 ‚Äì 8)
06:51 - 10:03 - HYMN R&S 34 Holy, Holy, Holy (Isaiah 6.3)
10:05 - Opening Prayer
11:24 - 26:03 - Introduction for all ages: ‚ÄòCollected Words‚Äô The Bible is a collection of different writings from various times and authors. The Old Testament contains 39 books, including history, poetry, and prophecy. Prophets spoke God's word into present situations, not just predicting the future. Isaiah is considered a major prophet, with the book named after him. The Book of Isaiah is a collection of prophecies spanning over 200 years. Scholars divide Isaiah into three parts: First Isaiah, Second Isaiah, and Third Isaiah. Isaiah's wife was also a prophetess, though not mentioned by name. The Book of Isaiah is often called the "Fifth Gospel" due to its connections to Jesus. The Dead Sea Scrolls, discovered in 1946, included a complete scroll of Isaiah. Jesus read from the scroll of Isaiah in the synagogue, selecting his own passage.
26:09 - 27:09 - Reading: Luke 4.16 ‚Äì 21 Good News read by Elsje Hatton
28:11 - 31:09 - HYMN R&S 591 Do not be afraid (Isaiah 41.1-4)
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing ‚Äì the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church
34:40 - 37:03 - Reading: Isaiah 55. 1 ‚Äì 13 NIVUK read by Tony Hatton
37:46 - 39:53 - HYMN R&S 415 You shall go out with joy (Isaiah 55.12) sung twice gently
40:12 - 48:10 - Short Address - Isaiah Isaiah's prophecies inspired Jesus and his followers. The book of Isaiah spans centuries and includes multiple prophetic voices. Jesus read from Isaiah in the synagogue, declaring its fulfillment in his ministry. Isaiah's words continue to inspire social justice and care for the vulnerable. The sermon references Wycombe Homeless Connection using Isaiah's words in their service. Isaiah's prophecies are seen as relevant for modern governments and society. The speaker emphasizes the enduring power of Isaiah's words across centuries. Isaiah 55 is highlighted as an invitation to seek God and find hope. The sermon notes God's thoughts and ways as higher than human understanding. It concludes with Isaiah's vision of creation rejoicing in God's redemption.
48:12 - 50:56 - Prayers of intercession World peace and justice Gratitude for compassionate people Local community organizations Political integrity Leadership for the common good Freedom for the oppressed Support for the vulnerable Homelessness and grief Illness and disability Personal intentions
Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus. When Isaiah was in the Temple and caught up in that vision of worship in heaven, he heard the voice of the Lord saying, ‚ÄòWhom shall I send and who will go for us?‚Äô
52:36 - 57:04 - HYMN MP 857 I the Lord of sea and sky (Isaiah 6.8)
57:09 - Prayer of thanksgiving
59:55 - The Lord‚Äôs Prayer (traditional words)
01:00:35 - Distribution of communion
01:05:36 - Closing Prayer
01:07:03 - 01:10:57 - HYMN MP 249 How lovely on the mountains (Isaiah 52.7) (popular version)
01:10:59 - 01:11:20 - Blessing (from Isaiah 58)
01:11:44 - 01:15:09 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 30th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
00:09 - Entry of the bible, welcome, lighting of the peace candle
02:23 - Call to worship: Psalm 130
03:32 - 05:45 - Hymn: R&S: 26 Father, we praise you now the night is over Tune: Christe Sanctorum
05:49 - Opening Prayers and the Lord‚Äôs Prayer
09:38 - 12:20 - Reading: Mark 5 v 21 ‚Äì 43 read by Richard
12:30 - 16:39 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) Enjoying the TV show "Doc Martin" with his wife Helen. An episode where a doctor has a poor bedside manner with a sick child. A doctor with a similar bedside manner at a care home. A coroner who trained that doctor described him as "just plain odd." Discussing a story about a young girl dying. A young person's death is particularly sad and impactful. Jesus is mentioned as offering the possibility of a rich and wonderful life after death. Working with dying people and those who are bereaved. A woman who felt it was wrong that her daughter died before her. The talk concludes by discussing Jesus bringing a young girl back to life and the promise of eternal life in Heaven.
16:52 - 19:32 - Hymn: R&S: 474 Brother, sister, let me serve you
19:35 - Blessing Junior Church for their activities May the Lord be with you: and also with you. Amen.
20:57 - 23:27 - Reading: 2 Corinthians 8 v 7 ‚Äì 15 read by John
23:52 - 27:13 - Hymn: R&S: 69 Lord of all being Tune: Ombersley
27:17 - Dedication of offertory
28:26 - 37:06 - Address followed by a time of quiet reflection Two healing stories from Mark 5:21-43, focusing on their interconnectedness. Mark's "sandwich" technique where one story is framed within another for emphasis. Jesus portrayed as accepting marginalized groups, including women, the sick, and the poor. The story of the woman with the issue of blood is highlighted as an example of Jesus' compassion. God's redemptive work in the midst of chaos is emphasized throughout scripture. Jesus' mission described as recovering the personhood of those marginalized by society. The church is called to challenge systems that maintain inequality and injustice. Christians are encouraged to reimagine their communities through God's love. Jesus' interaction with the woman demonstrates his protection of her dignity and identity. The sermon concludes with a call for the church to be invitational and inclusive, showing compassion to all.
37:31 - 41:22 - Hymn: R&S: 551 O for a closer walk with God Tune: Avon
41:36 - 47:03 - Prayers of intercession
47:25 - 50:52 - Hymn: R&S: 95 God is love let heaven adore him Tune: Blaenwern
50:53 - 51:14 - Closing blessing
52:05 - 54:46 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 24th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
03:28 - Entry of the bible
03:45 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:45 - Call to worship
08:57 - 12:42 - Hymn Praise, my soul the King of Heaven [Tune: Praise, my soul]
12:54 - Opening Prayers 15:01 - The Lord‚Äôs Prayer (traditional words)
16:07 - 22:20 - Introductory Talk for all ages ‚Äì How do we manage when people want to do things differently to us? Managing conflicting desires between people. Examples of conflicts between a child and his grandmother. Conflict and how to manage differing wants and needs.
23:42 - 26:04 - Hymn Father, I place into your hands [Tune: Father, I place into..]
26:40 - Introduction to the readings
27:06 - 29:30 - 1st Reading: Jeremiah 10. 1 ‚Äì 16 read by Linda
30:37 - 32:16 - 2nd Reading: Romans 11. 25 ‚Äì 36 read by Kate
32:32 - 36:30 - Hymn Just as I am, without one plea [Tune: Saffron Waldon]
36:35 - 48:35 - Address - followed by time of quiet reflection Discussing God and worship, drawing from Old and New Testament readings. Even the chosen people of Israel struggled with proper worship. Jeremiah's role as a prophet criticizing political and religious leadership. The historical context of Jeremiah's prophecies during Babylonian rule. Drawing parallels between ancient idol worship and modern-day practices. The establishment of the church in Rome and Paul's letter to the Romans. Conflicts between Jewish and Gentile Christians in early Rome. Paul's message of continuity in God's purpose for Jews and Gentiles. Questioning Paul's explanation of God's purpose in uniting Jews and Gentiles. Emphasizing humility, loving God, and loving one's neighbor despite differences.
49:01 - 50:52 - Hymn Head of the church, our risen Lord [Tune: Melcombe]
50:58 - 55:33 - Prayers of intercession
56:01 - 59:58 - Hymn To God be the glory, [Tune: To God be the glory]
01:00:04 - 01:00:34 - Blessing
01:00:53 - 01:04:20 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 16th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:30 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
04:43 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
05:59 - Call to worship (from Psalm 104) Praise the¬†LORD, my soul! Lord my God, how great you are! You make springs flow in the valleys, and rivers run between the hills. In the trees near by, the birds make their nests and sing. From the sky you send rain on the hills, and the earth is filled with your blessings. All creatures ‚Äì and we ourselves - depend on you: when you open your hand, all are satisfied with good things.
07:22 - 10:06 - HYMN R&S 117 O Lord my God (vs. 1 and 2 only)
10:10 - Opening Prayer with the response For all your gifts and blessings: We praise you, God of all people.
17:55 - 22:34 - Introduction: ‚ÄòElijah the outsider‚Äô
23:21 - 25:07 - Reading: 1 Kings 17. 1 ‚Äì 10 read by Rosemary Taylor
25:35 - 36:30 - Talk: ‚ÄòFed by the ravens!‚Äô The importance of serving God, not idols or selfish interests, like Elijah served the God of Israel. The story of Elijah being fed by ravens highlights humanity's interconnectedness with nature. Questioning the belief that humans are superior to nature and can live without it. The story of the widow's unending flour and oil symbolizes God's provision in times of scarcity. The valuable role of the poor widow in helping Elijah. Jesus referenced the story of the widow, praising those who give even a cup of water. The need for recognizing interdependence and reliance on God. Jesus' teaching about God's care for even small sparrows. Praying to God as a caring, heavenly Father.
Pause: ‚ÄòHappy Father‚Äôs Day!‚Äô
36:48 - Lord‚Äôs Prayer
37:40 - 40:29 - HYMN R&S 64 I lift my eyes to the quiet hills
40:40 - 44:00 - Consider:¬†How do you react to a crisis or a danger in your life? Do you prefer to ‚Äòfight‚Äô or prefer ‚Äòflight‚Äô or simply ‚Äòfreeze‚Äô?!
44:04 - 47:06 - Reading: 1 Kings 19.9 ‚Äì 20a read by Norma Garden
47:19 - 57:44 - Reflection: ‚Äòmeeting God in the silence‚Äô Elijah depressed and in self-pity after his triumph over the prophets of Baal. Elijah catastrophized, feeling alone and that everyone had deserted him except for God. God questioned Elijah's presence in the cave, calling him out of his despair and isolation. Rather than appearing in dramatic natural phenomena, God came to Elijah in a "gentle whisper" or "still small voice." Contrast the noise of our world with the stark silence Elijah experienced in the cave. Silence is challenging yet powerful, allowing space for God's voice amidst the inner noise of thoughts. Different translations describing God's voice as a "soft whisper," "sound of sheer silence," and "still small voice." Elijah realized he was in the presence of the holy God, covering his face in response. God met Elijah not in dramatic displays but in the stillness and quiet whisper.
Ponder: ‚ÄòWe spend most of our lives focussed on three verbs: to want, to have and to do. But none of these verbs has any ultimate significance until it is transcended by and included in the fundamental verb: to be.‚Äô (Evelyn Underhill)
58:25 - 01:00:32 - HYMN MP 48 Be still and know that I am God
01:00:59 - Further Exploration: ‚ÄòJesus and Elijah‚Äô
01:03:26 - 01:05:53 - Reading: Matthew 17. 1 ‚Äì 13 read by Terry
01:06:11 - 01:10:58 - HYMN R&S 492 Dear Lord and Father of mankind
01:11:19 - 01:18:48 - Prayers for the church and the world using verses of HYMN TP 56 Kum ba ya
01:19:04 - 01:21:59 - HYMN R&S 531 Lord of all hopefulness
01:22:00 - 01:22:17 - Blessing
01:22:47 - 01:25:31 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 2nd June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
07:49 - Entry of the Bible
07:58 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
10:01 - Call to worship
10:59 - 14:07 - HYMN R&S 102 Praise the Lord
14:08 - 16:00 - Prayer of adoration and confession
16:08 - 24:49 - Introduction for all ages: ‚ÄòNothing like a good story‚Äô Favourite stories, parables, and losing things
25:27 - 27:02 - Reading: Luke 15. 1 ‚Äì 10 NIVUK read by Lesley Bogart
29:14 - 31:17 - HYMN CP 695 God has given us a book full of stories 31:25 - 33:06 - TP 31 Give thanks with a grateful heart (Activities for children are available during the service)
34:18 - 39:41 - Talk - Prophets The role of prophets in ancient Israel, including major and minor prophets in the Old and New Testaments. Prophets were honest truth-tellers close to God, sometimes speaking out at great personal cost. Prophecy involved discerning the signs of the times and God's wisdom, not just future predictions. There were also female prophets like Miriam, Deborah, and Isaiah's wife, though less known. The story of the prophet Nathan confronting King David over his sin with Bathsheba is examined. David abused his power by summoning Bathsheba and impregnating her, then ordering her husband Uriah's death. Nathan uses a parable to make David realize his guilt before directly accusing him. The prophets called for repentance and change, as the future was not set. David repents after Nathan's confrontation, though he still faces consequences. Prophecy involved speaking truth to power, even to kings who could have the prophet killed.
40:00 - 42:21 - Reading: 2 Samuel 12. 1 ‚Äì 10 NIVUK read by Ian Bogart
43:35 - 47:37 - HYMN R&S 621 Almighty Father
47:41 - 01:00:06 - Short Address Jesus was dismissed as just a carpenter when he returned to his hometown of Nazareth, but he embraced the title of prophet. Honoring the prophets and hearing what they have to say, especially during political campaigns filled with empty words and promises. The story of the prophet Nathan confronting King David about his sin with Bathsheba is examined. Nathan uses a parable to make David realize his own guilt before directly accusing him, showing the power of stories. Prophets are called to speak truth to power, even at great personal risk. There are consequences for sin, as seen in David's family being divided by conflict after his actions. However, genuine repentance like David's leads to God's forgiveness, though consequences may still remain. A parallel between the injustice done to the poor man's lamb and the injustice of Jesus' death. Encouraging hearing the stories of the poor and marginalized in society. Despite sin and tragedy, there is hope for a new beginning through God's grace and truth.
01:01:29 - 01:06:27 - Prayers of intercession with the response Lord, may your kingdom of justice and joy come: your loving will be done.
Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus.
01:10:29 - HYMN TP 48 Jesus calls us here
01:10:59 - 01:12:57 - Prayer of thanksgiving The Lord‚Äôs Prayer (traditional words)
01:13:04 - 01:18:56 - Distribution of communion Closing Prayer
01:19:11 - 01:21:24 - HYMN R&S 30 Father we love you
01:21:25 - 01:21:52 - Blessing
01:22:19 - 01:25:04 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th May 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
03:21 - Entry of the Bible
03:37 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
05:48 - Call to Worship (Psalm 27. 1 ‚Äì 4)
06:50 - 10:46 - HYMN R&S 121 The God of Abraham praise
11:19 - Opening Prayers Lord‚Äôs Prayer
14:16 - 17:07 - Reading: John 3. 1 ‚Äì 17 read by Alan Yates
17:19 - 22:03 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) The film "Nuns on the Run" starring Robbie Coltrane and Eric Idle. In the film, two criminals disguise themselves as nuns to hide in a convent after a bank robbery. The Mother Superior allows them to stay but requires them to work like the other nuns. A humorous scene where Eric Idle's character, Sister Immaculata, tries to explain the Holy Trinity to a class of teenage girls. Sister Immaculata uses a three-leaf clover to illustrate the concept of the Trinity. A triangle, being a strong shape, can represent the strength and self-supporting nature of the Trinity. Parallels between the three sides of the triangle and the three persons of the Trinity: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. The Trinity is a difficult concept for humans to fully understand. However, the triangle analogy can help provide a partial understanding of how God can be three persons in one. Think about the triangle next time you contemplate the Trinity, as it represents God's ability to be Father, Son, and Holy Spirit simultaneously.
22:15 - 25:47 - HYMN R&S 34 Holy, Holy, Holy Lord God Almighty
26:00 - 27:12 - Reading: Romans 8. 12 ‚Äì 17 read by Kate Yates
27:31 - 34:16 - HYMN R&S 36 I bind unto myself today
34:25 - 42:58 - Address The comedy series Dad's Army and a humorous scene about choir admission forms. The ancient Athanasian Creed, which explains the doctrine of the Holy Trinity. The Creed stresses that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are one God, yet distinct persons. The Trinity is a difficult concept for many Christians to comprehend. However, the Trinity represents a model of perfect balance, communion, and relationship within God. There is no domination or power struggle among the three persons, only absolute love. The Trinitarian relationship is meant to be an example for human relationships and love. Through Christ, believers are mysteriously drawn into this relationship of divine love. The Trinity is not just an academic doctrine but part of the believer's experience of God. The image of God as a loving Trinity is stamped into human beings from creation.
43:28 - 46:05 - HYMN R&S 38 Thou Whose Almighty word
46:10 - 51:40 - Prayers of intercession
51:59 - 54:39 - HYMN R&S 405 Angel voices ever singing
54:39 - 55:01 - Blessing
55:25 - 59:10 - Music after the service

Christian Aid helped Alen through a community workshop and Village Savings and Loans Association (VSLA). Alen's dream of getting her children back became possible after the workshop. Where is Burundi?

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 5th May 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
03:07 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
03:21 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
05:16 - Call to worship
05:56 - Hymn - MP 77 Christ triumphant (Tune Christ triumphant)
09:07 - Prayer of adoration and confession
11:43 - 19:52 - Introduction for all ages: ‚ÄòNo End!‚Äô The Premier League season ends on May 19th. Spring officially ends on June 21st, and summer begins. The Paris Olympics will end on August 11th. The Gospel of Mark ends with "for they were afraid." The Gospel of John ends with "the whole world would not have room for the books that would be written about the deeds of Jesus." The Gospel of Luke ends with "and they stayed continually at the temple praising God." The Gospel of Matthew ends with "I will be with you always, to the very end of the age." Ascension Day marks the beginning of the "Thy Kingdom Come" global prayer movement. Christian Aid Week begins next week, with envelopes being distributed for donations. The church is participating in a 24/7 prayer event on May 21st, and prayer walking around the town leading up to a service on June 9th.

28:06 - 2945 - Hymn - Hosanna
30:29 - 43:47 - Short Address - Sing a New Song: Worshiping the Marvelous God of All Creation Worshiping together openly, not in fear or isolation. The nature of true worship as described by William Temple - submission of all our nature to God. Ascension Day is highlighted, and the sermon explores the meaning behind Jesus being "taken up into the clouds." The disciples' reaction to Jesus' ascension was joy and continual praise, not sadness. Rreconnect with the "marvelous things" God has done, especially through Jesus. God's salvation and love extend beyond just one nation or people, reaching to all the ends of the earth. All of creation - humanity, nature, rivers, mountains - is invited to join in worship and song to God. God's coming judgment is portrayed as an assurance of setting things right and establishing righteousness. A call to pray for and anticipate God's kingdom and will being done on earth.
43:50 - 47:37 - Prayers of intercession (including short times of silence)
47:41 - Communion: we invite all to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus, united in his name.

59:46 - Closing Prayer

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 28th April 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
06:20 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
08:22 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
09:45 - Call to Worship - Psalm 22. 27 -31
10:43 - 14:33 - Hymn R&S 236 Come, ye faithful, raise the strain
14:36 - Opening Prayers and the Lord‚Äôs Prayer
17:49 - 19:18 - Reading: John 15. 1 ‚Äì 8 read by Sue Thorne
19:26 - 23:22 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) Not being much of a gardener and finding it a waste of time An exception was a small plant grown from a single leaf given out at an Easter Sunday service a few years ago. The leaf was told to be planted upside down in potting compost, and surprisingly it took root and grew into a sizable plant. This plant taught the lesson that we need to be part of something - specifically, attached to Jesus who is the true vine. Jesus provides the life-giving energy and sustenance for us to bear good fruit and do his work. If we take this seriously and do the work Jesus desires, our spiritual fruit would multiply and increase our impact. Jesus said he is the true vine, and God the Father is the gardener who prunes the branches. Branches must remain attached to the vine (Jesus) to receive the life-giving sap and produce fruit. To bear the fruits of love, joy, peace, patience, etc., we must stay connected to Jesus as our source. It is important to stay in touch with Jesus every single day of our lives to receive his life in us.
23:32 - 26:34 - Hymn R&S 234 Alleluia, alleluia, give thanks
27:10 - 30:40 - Reading: Acts 8. 26 ‚Äì 40 read by John Hillson
30:59 - 34:01 - Hymn R&S 71 O God of Bethel, by whose hand
34:32 - 46:06 - Address Two important words to consider today - inclusivity and diversity Policies and actions need to be evaluated for promoting inclusivity and diversity for all people regardless of gender, family situation, disability, lifestyle, or racial background. The Gospel story challenges us to consider the radical inclusivity and diversity of God's love revealed in Jesus. The Ethiopian eunuch was a powerful court official who was physically impotent/castrated, likely non-Jewish and from the ancient kingdom of Kush. He was reading Isaiah's suffering servant prophecies about Jesus, but was excluded from the Jerusalem temple as a eunuch. Yet Isaiah promises inclusion for foreigners and eunuchs who keep God's covenant. This prefigures the church's expansion from Jewish followers of Jesus to the whole world. The eunuch, excluded from societal binaries, may have been nearer to God and invited Philip to join him. Like Philip, the church needs to be open to meeting people on their territory, not just inviting them into church buildings.
46:33 - 51:07 - Hymn R&S 623 Eternal Ruler of the ceaseless round
51:11 - 56:29 - Prayers of intercession
56:48 - 01:00:36 - Hymn R&S 605 Son of God, eternal Saviour
01:00:37 - 01:01:07 - Blessing
01:01:29 - 01:04:27 - Music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 21st April 2024 - Forth Sunday of Easter
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
02:11 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
03:48 - Call to worship (1 Peter 1.3)
04:13 - 07:54 - Hymn - God is love
08:03 - Prayer of adoration and confession The Lord‚Äôs Prayer (traditional words)
10:07 - 19:55 - Introduction for all ages: ‚ÄòPassing on the message‚Äô
20:17 - 21:42 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 15. 1 ‚Äì 10 read by Sarah
23:21 - Affirmation: Christ died for our sins. Christ was buried in the tomb. Christ was raised to life eternal. Christ appeared and is with us now. Thank you Jesus Thank you Lord.
24:29 - Hymns - All heaven declares, Jesus, hope of the nations
30:15 - Introducing second reading
32:09 - 33:39 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 15. 12 ‚Äì 20 read by Norma
33:52 - 41:47 - Talk: ‚ÄòChrist‚Äôs risen life and ours‚Äô
42:07 - 45:08 - Hymn - Jesus lives!
45:39 - 49:08 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 15.35 ‚Äì 45, 51 ‚Äì 58 read by Sarah and Norma
49:16 - 56:10 - Talk - ‚Äòunfolding a mystery‚Äô The passage (1 Corinthians 15) begins and ends with questions about resurrection and the defeat of death. Paul delights in the diversity and splendor of the natural world. Resurrection is not about endless, indefinite life extension, but transformation into a new, imperishable existence. What is perishable, dishonorable, weak, and natural will be raised imperishable, glorious, powerful, and spiritual - a mystery beyond our imagination. Death is a fundamental reality of human existence, but not the final reality; God revealed in the risen Christ is the final reality. We are all diminished by each person's death, but connected through the risen Jesus who brings hope. John Donne's poem depicting death as temporary: "one short sleep past, we wake eternally." Drawing from Isaiah, Paul declares death is "swallowed up in victory" through Christ's resurrection. The "sting" of death is sin, but God gives ultimate victory over sin and death through Jesus Christ. Our labor for God's kingdom is not in vain, bearing fruit in this life and beyond, when we live in hope, faith, and eternal love.
56:30 - 59:10 - Hymn Now the green blade rises
59:14 - 01:04:36 - Prayers of thanksgiving and intercession with the response Lord of all life: hear our prayer.
01:04:52 - 01:07:33 - Hymn - R&S 260 Christ is alive!
01:07:34 - 01:08:06 - Blessing
01:08:33 - 01:12:40 - Music after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - 14th April 2024 - Third Sunday of Easter

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 14th April 2024 - Third Sunday of Easter
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
05:35 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
06:27 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:49 - Call to worship (Luke 24 v5b-6a) Why do you look for the living among the dead? He is not here; he has risen!‚Äù
09:46 - 12:26 - Hymn R&S 246: The day of resurrection (Tune: Ellacombe CP230)
12:33 - 15:26 - Opening Prayers and the Lord‚Äôs Prayer
15:33 - 21:03 - Introductory Talk ‚Äì Symbols of the cross
21:19 - 24:17 - Hymn R&S 234: Alleluia, Alleluia, give thanks
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing ‚Äì the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church
24:35 - Introduction to the readings
26:17 - 27:56 - 1st Reading: Luke 24. 36 ‚Äì 48 read by Lesley Bogart
28:39 - 30:14 - 2nd Reading: Acts 3. 12 ‚Äì 19 read by Ian Bogart
30:41 - 34:18 - Hymn R&S 373: Lord Jesus Christ, you have come to us
34:25 - 52:17 - Address - followed by time of quiet reflection The apparent doubt experienced by the disciples when Jesus appeared to them after his resurrection. The disciples' doubt is encouraging, as it shows that it's okay to have doubts in one's faith. The external context and events that can bring doubts into people's minds, but God is not responsible for these. The core message of the Gospel, which is that Jesus died so that people can repent and be forgiven. The concept of being "justified" by Christ's death on the cross, meaning that one is seen as if they had never sinned. The message of repentance and forgiveness of sins is central to the Gospel, as seen in the passages from Luke and Acts. What would we have done if Jesus had lived among us - people can sometimes be carried away by the crowd. Regardless of past actions, people can be forgiven by God if they truly repent. The commission Jesus gave to his disciples, which is to share the good news and encourage people to repent and be forgiven. Allow the Holy Spirit to open their minds to the scriptures and empower them to share the Gospel message.
55:02 - 58:57 - Hymn R&S 364: Just as I am, without one plea

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 24th March 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
05:09 - Entry of the bible and welcome
06:35 - Lighting of the peace candle
07:50 - Call to Worship The blessing of the palms
10:11 - 13:03 - Hymn - All Glory Lord and honour
10:15 - The distribution of the palms
13:07 - 16:25 - Opening Prayers and the Lord‚Äôs Prayer
16:50 - 17:35 - Reading: John 12. 12 -16 NIVUK read by Linda
17:48 - 20:51 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) Jesus' welcome into Jerusalem Jesus received a triumphant welcome into Jerusalem, with people waving palm branches and shouting "Hosanna!" The crowd welcomed Jesus as the new King, expecting him to overthrow the Romans and establish God's kingdom. We can be like that crowd, getting excited about Jesus and promising to work for his kingdom. We pray, worship, give, and strive to live loving and honest lives in service to God's will. Yet the same crowd that praised Jesus also turned on him, shouting "Crucify him!" There are times when we similarly reject Jesus' way of love, humility, and obedience. In those moments, we join the crowd calling for Jesus' crucifixion. We struggle to fully embrace the demands of God's kingdom when it conflicts with our desires. The call is to consistently live "Hosanna!" with our lives, not rejecting Christ's lordship. We must continually realign our hearts to receive Jesus as King, not just in celebratory moments.
21:05 - 23:09 - Hymn Ride on ride on in majesty
Blessing as Junior Church leave.
24:16 - 26:58 - Reading Mark 14. 1 ‚Äì 15 NIVUK read by Kitty
27:17 - 31:20 - Hymn As Royal banners are unfurled (Tune Gonfalon Royal)
31:56 - 45:32 - Address - From Palms to Passion: A Holy Week Journey We are called to embrace the solemn and reflective nature of Lent as a season of repentance and preparation. We witness the climax of the passion narrative during Holy Week, accompanying Jesus from his triumphal entry to his crucifixion and resurrection. we recognize the extravagant act of the woman who anointed Jesus with expensive perfume as a beautiful expression of devotion. We are challenged to move beyond the "market mind" that sees such acts as wasteful, and instead appreciate the spiritual value. We are invited to lift your worship and service to the level of beauty, going beyond the minimum with unsolicited gifts of love. We are encouraged to do what you can, even if it seems unexciting or unspectacular, as that is often the highest achievement. We are reminded that true discipleship involves transforming duty into the maximum of beauty through the "fine excess" of imagination and love. We are called to echo the hosannas that proclaimed Jesus as the long-awaited King during his triumphal entry into Jerusalem. We are urged to accompany Jesus on his journey from Palm Sunday to Easter, immersing yourselves in the profound liturgies and symbolism. We are exhorted to live out the self-giving, unmeasured generosity exemplified by the woman who anointed Jesus.
45:57 - 49:44 - Hymn When I survey the wondrous cross
49:49 - 54:26 - Prayers of intercession
54:45 - 56:53 - Hymn In the cross of Christ I glory
56:53 - 57:15 - Blessing
57:41 - 01:01:34 - Music after the service
